docs.snippet: Pitchers are striking out batters in record numbers amid a heavier reliance on bullpens and greater specialization among relievers....
docs.lead_paragraph: Pitchers are striking out batters in record numbers amid a heavier reliance on bullpens and greater specialization among relievers.
docs.abstract: Pitchers have emerged as the dominant force in major league baseball, striking out hitters at the highest rate in at least 20 years and bringing a definitive end to the home run era; shift comes amid a heavier reliance on bullpens and a greater specialization among relievers.

headline.main: Many Strikeouts, Fewer Runs as Pitchers Take Control

docs.snippet: Each time one of the Dodgers hits a home run and returns to the dugout, he is greeted by a stream of small, soapy bubbles emanating from a pair of toy machines....
docs.lead_paragraph: Each time one of the Dodgers hits a home run and returns to the dugout, he is greeted by a stream of small, soapy bubbles emanating from a pair of toy machines.
docs.abstract: Dugout bubble machine has become part of deeply-ingrained home run ritual for the Los Angeles Dodgers, though some have questioned whether celebration is charming or childish.

headline.main: Dugout Ritual Honors Swings With Extra Pop
headline.print_headline: Dugout Ritual Honors Swings With Extra Pop

docs.snippet: Shuba, a Dodgers outfielder, is remembered for a welcoming gesture to Jackie Robinson on the day that Robinson, as a minor leaguer, broke baseball’s color barrier....
docs.lead_paragraph: Shuba, a Dodgers outfielder, is remembered for a welcoming gesture to Jackie Robinson on the day that Robinson, as a minor leaguer, broke baseball’s color barrier.
docs.abstract: George Shuba, Brooklyn Dodgers outfielder who played in three World Series during the 1950s and welcomed Jackie Robinson at home plate when he broke the color barrier, dies at age 89.

headline.main: George Shuba, 89, Dies; Handshake Heralded Racial Tolerance in Baseball
headline.print_headline: George Shuba Dies at 89; Offered Tolerant Gesture

docs.snippet: It had been 29 years since the Kansas City Royals had last been to the postseason — nearly three decades spent mostly in baseball's backwater, a small-market organization on a shoe-string budget trying in vain to compete with the big boys....
